entry.title: Re: A fee-bumping model
entry.summary:
The discussion opens with concerns regarding the privacy implications of watchtowers in blockchain technology, highlighting a gap in ensuring transaction confirmations at any given fee rate. The dialogue suggests that the assumption that past fee rates should influence future transactions is flawed, proposing instead that the strategy for when to increase transaction fees (fee-bumping) needs reconsideration. It's suggested that rather than having a fixed schedule, a dynamic approach based on the network conditions and block connections might be more efficient. This could involve initial attempts to transact at lower fee rates, followed by more aggressive fee increases if the transaction is not confirmed within a certain number of blocks.
The conversation also critiques the `estimatesmartfee` RPC call, pointing out its limitations and suggesting the potential for an insurance market within the cryptocurrency space. This market could leverage discreet log contracts, albeit with some trust assumptions and the involvement of multiple oracles. An innovative idea is shared about creating an insurance project specifically tailored for the LGBTQ community in India, addressing the lack of sufficient options available to them. This proposal is detailed further in a linked [Gist document](https://gist.github.com/prayank23/f30ab1ab68bffe6bcb2ceacec599cd36).
Lastly, the email references a presentation by Jack Mallers that explores the possibility of creating derivatives for users to hedge against transaction fees. This concept is seen as a way to mitigate the unpredictability and sometimes high cost of transaction fees within the blockchain network. The presentation is available for further insight at [YouTube](https://youtu.be/rBCG0btUlTw). This summary encapsulates the main points discussed in the email, focusing on the challenges and proposed solutions regarding transaction fee management and the innovative use of insurance within the blockchain ecosystem.
